facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 94 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 94 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1951 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 81 of 1959. V. Viswanatha Sastri and P.K. Ghosh, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1951 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 81 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1951 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 81 of 1959. V. Viswanatha Sastri and P.K. Ghosh, for the appellant. K. Chatterjee and P.K. Bose, for the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant is a public limited company registered as a dealer under the Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act, 1941, with registered place of business at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are as follows The appellant is a public limited companypany registered as a dealer under the Act, having its registered place of business at Calcutta. In respect of the accounting year ending with 31st December 1954, in the return for the year the assessee had shown its gross turnover at Rs. 70,99,928-10-0

facts.text: Accounting year ending 31st December 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the accounting year ending with 31st December 1954, in the return for the year the assessee had shown its gross turnover at Rs. 70,99,928-10-0 and claimed exemption under two heads, namely,  i  under s. 5 2  a  i  of the Act Rs. 1,33,730-6-6 and  ii  under s. 5 2  a  ii  thereof Rs. 69,65,979-9-6.

facts.text: In return for the year, assessee showed gross turnover at Rs. 70,99,928-10-0.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee had shown its gross turnover at Rs. 70,99,928-10-0 and claimed exemption under two heads, namely,  i  under s. 5 2  a  i  of the Act Rs. 1,33,730-6-6 and  ii  under s. 5 2  a  ii  thereof Rs. 69,65,979-9-6. After deducting the said amounts from the gross turnover the assessee showed its taxable turnover at Rs. 218-9-0

facts.text: Assessee claimed exemption under s.5(2)(a)(i) Rs. 1,33,730-6-6 and under s.5(2)(a)(ii) Rs. 69,65,979-9-6.

anchor.surface_text: and claimed exemption under two heads, namely,  i  under s. 5 2  a  i  of the Act Rs. 1,33,730-6-6 and  ii  under s. 5 2  a  ii  thereof Rs. 69,65,979-9-6. After deducting the said amounts from the gross turnover the assessee showed its taxable turnover at Rs. 218-9-0 and deposited the tax of Rs. 9-12-6 on the said amount in the treasury.

facts.text: After deductions, assessee showed taxable turnover at Rs. 218-9-0 and deposited tax of Rs. 9-12-6.

anchor.surface_text: After deducting the said amounts from the gross turnover the assessee showed its taxable turnover at Rs. 218-9-0 and deposited the tax of Rs. 9-12-6 on the said amount in the treasury. The Commercial Tax Officer by numberice dated April 22, 1955, fixed August 4, 1955, for hearing the assessee in respect of its return.

facts.text: Commercial Tax Officer issued notice dated April 22, 1955, fixing hearing on August 4, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer by numberice dated April 22, 1955, fixed August 4, 1955, for hearing the assessee in respect of its return. Under s. 5 2  a  ii , the appellant in order to claim exemption thereunder had to furnish declaration forms duly filled in and signed by registered dealers to whom the goods were sold by it.

facts.text: In second week of January 1957, assessee's file containing 147 declaration forms was missing.

anchor.surface_text: After taking some adjournments of the enquiry it appears that in the second week of January 1957 the assessee found that its file companytaining 147 declaration forms received from its dealers in respect of the goods received from it was missing.

facts.text: Assessee made attempts to get duplicate declaration forms from dealers but could not due to circumstances and unhelpful attitude of Commercial Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, it is said, made various attempts to get duplicate forms of declaration from the dealers, but, on account of circumstances over which it had numbercontrol and because of the unhelpful and hostile attitude of the Commercial Tax Officer within whose jurisdiction the said dealers functioned, it was number able to furnish the duplicate forms for all the declarations that were lost.

facts.text: On August 8, 1957, assessee applied to Commercial Tax Officer under s.21A to summon dealers.

anchor.surface_text: On August 8, 1957, the assessee applied to the Commercial Tax Officer under s. 21A of the Act for summoning the dealers to produce the necessary documents in order to prove that they had issued the declaration forms to it, but the said officer did number issue the requisite summons to the parties companycerned.

facts.text: Commercial Tax Officer did not issue summons to the dealers.

anchor.surface_text: but the said officer did number issue the requisite summons to the parties companycerned. The assessee then flied an application to the Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, West Bengal, for directions to issue duplicate declaration forms, but that application was rejected.

facts.text: Assessee applied to Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, West Bengal for duplicate declaration forms, but rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then flied an application to the Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, West Bengal, for directions to issue duplicate declaration forms, but that application was rejected. The revision filed to the Revenue Board was also dismissed.

facts.text: Revision to Revenue Board was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The revision filed to the Revenue Board was also dismissed. On November 21, 1957, the Commercial Tax Officer made an order of assessment disallowing the assessees claim for exemption in respect of the said sales made to the purchasing registered dealers amounting to Rs. 22,46,006-0-6

facts.text: On November 21, 1957, Commercial Tax Officer made assessment order disallowing exemption for sales Rs. 22,46,006-0-6 and levied additional tax Rs. 1,49,778-4-6.

anchor.surface_text: On November 21, 1957, the Commercial Tax Officer made an order of assessment disallowing the assessees claim for exemption in respect of the said sales made to the purchasing registered dealers amounting to Rs. 22,46,006-0-6 and levied on it additional tax of Rs. 1,49,778-4-6.

facts.text: Assessee filed petition under Art. 226 in Calcutta High Court against Commercial Tax Officer and Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee thereafter flied a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Calcutta for issuing an order directing the respondents, i.e., the Commercial Tax Officer and the Commissioner of Commercial Taxes. West Bengal, number to implement the said assessment order.

facts.text: Sinha J. dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The said application came up, at the first instance, before Sinha, J., who dismissed the same. On appeal, a Division Bench of the said High Court companyfirmed the order of Sinha, J. Hence the present appeal.

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court confirmed order of Sinha J.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, a Division Bench of the said High Court companyfirmed the order of Sinha, J. Hence the present appeal. facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate granted by Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Calcutta raises the question of the interpretation of s. 5 2  a   ii  of the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941  Bengal Act VI of 1941 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court does not decide if department was responsible for preventing furnishing of duplicate forms or wrong in not summoning dealers.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset we must make it clear that in the view we are taking on the companystruction of s. 5 of the Act we do number propose to go into the question whether the department was responsible for preventing the assessee from furnishing duplicate forms of the declarations alleged to have been lost or on the question whether the department went wrong in number summoning the dealers to produce the relevant documents

issues.text: the question of the interpretation of s. 5(2)(a)(ii) of the Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act, 1941

anchor.surface_text: interpretation of s. 5 2  a   ii  of the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941  Bengal Act VI of 1941 , hereinafter called the Act.

issues.text: whether the department went wrong in not summoning the dealers to produce the relevant documents to establish that the declaration forms alleged to have been lost were in fact issued by them

The only question, therefore, that arises is whether under s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act the furnishing of the declaration forms issued by the purchasing dealers

issues.text: whether under s. 5(2)(a)(ii) of the Act the furnishing of the declaration forms issued by the purchasing dealers was a condition for claiming the exemption thereunder

anchor.surface_text: The only question, therefore, that arises is whether under s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act the furnishing of the declaration forms issued by the purchasing dealers was a condition for claiming the exemption thereunder. In substance s. 5 2  a  ii  exempts from taxable turnover all sales to a registered dealer of goods of the class or classes specified in the certificate of registration of the dealer as being intended for the purposes mentioned, therein. But the said exemption is made subject to a proviso.

arguments.claim: The proviso to s.5(2)(a)(ii) prescribes declaration form as best evidence of purpose but is only directory provision to subserve substantive exemption, not a mandatory condition for exemption

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to the said subclause prescribes in effect that the declaration form in the manner prescribed is the best evidence to prove that the sales were for the said purposes. The proviso cannot be construed as laying down a condition for giving the exemption, but only as a directory provision to subserve the substantive provision in a reasonable way.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso qualifies substantive exemption clause; strict construction required; ignoring proviso defeats legislative intent

arguments.claim: A dealer not precluded from producing other relevant evidence if proviso cannot be strictly complied with

anchor.surface_text: If so construed, a dealer is not precluded in a case where the proviso cannot be strictly complied with from producing other relevant evidence to prove that the sales to the registered dealers were for the purposes mentioned in the said sub-clause.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: egistered dealers were for the purposes mentioned in the said sub-clause. This companyclusion is sought to be supported on the basis of the expression

arguments.court_reasoning: Would rewrite clause and omit proviso; no provision to replace lost forms with other evidence

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor General, on the other hand, contends on behalf of the respondents that a dealer can claim exemption under the said sub-clause, but if he seeks exemption he must comply strictly with the conditions under which the exemption can be granted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Strict construction of exemption provisions; proviso imposes condition qualifying substantive clause

arguments.claim: Clear terms of clause read with proviso impose condition of furnishing declaration for claiming exemption

anchor.surface_text: He argues that the clear terms of the clause, read with the proviso, impose a condition on a dealer for claiming exemption.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rovides for the exemption in respect of certain sales to a dealer if the sales are made to a registered dealer for the purposes mentioned thereunder.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso qualifies exemption; dealer cannot claim unless furnishes prescribed declaration

arguments.claim: Tax exemption provisions must be strictly construed

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in effect exempts a specified turnover of a dealer from sales tax. The provision prescribing the exemption shall, therefore, be strictly construed.

arguments.claim: Proviso qualifies substantive clause; exemption subject to furnishing prescribed declaration

anchor.surface_text: The substantive clause gives the exemption and the proviso qualifies the substantive clause. In effect the proviso says that part of the turnover of the selling dealer covered by the terms of sub-cl. ii will be exempted provided a declaration in the form prescribed is furnished.

arguments.claim: Qualifying proviso excepts or qualifies preceding enactment; ignoring it defeats legislative intent

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the effect of an excepting or qualifying proviso, according to the ordinary rules of construction, is to except out of the preceding portion of the enactment, or to qualify something enacted therein,

arguments.claim: r.27A 'on demand' fixes time for producing declaration, harmonious with s.5(2)(a)(ii)

anchor.surface_text: Nor does r. 27A support the contrary construction. The expression on demand only fixes the point of time when the declaration forms are to be produced otherwise the rule would be inconsistent with the section.

arguments.claim: s.21A does not enable ignoring statutory condition for exemption despite power to summon evidence

anchor.surface_text: Section 21A on which reliance is placed has no bearing on the question to be decided. It only empowers the Commissioner or any person appointed to assist him under sub-s. 1 of s. 3 to take evidence on oath etc.

arguments.claim: No provision under rules for duplicate forms or compelling issuance thereof

anchor.surface_text: Sub-rules 3 and 4 of r. 27A are not helpful to the appellant. They provide only safeguards against abuse of the declaration forms by the purchasing dealers they do not enable the selling dealer to either directly apply or to compel the purchasing dealers to apply for duplicate forms

arguments.claim: Stringent provisions prevent fraud, collusion and administrative inconvenience

anchor.surface_text: There is an understandable reason for the stringency of the provisions. The object of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act and the rules made thereunder is self-evident. While they are obviously intended to give exemption to a dealer in respect of sales to registered dealers of specified classes of goods, it seeks also to prevent fraud and collusion

arguments.claim: State of Orissa v. M.A. Tulloch distinguishable as no conditioning proviso; rule directory there

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in The State of Orissa v. M.A. Tulloch and Co. Ltd. 1 does not help the appellant. That decision was concerned with s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947. That section was similar in terms to s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in question, but there was no proviso to that section

holdings.text: The provision prescribing the exemption shall, therefore, be strictly construed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in effect exempts a specified turnover of a dealer from sales tax. The provision prescribing the exemption shall, therefore, be strictly construed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemptions from sales tax exempt specified turnover and must be strictly construed.

holdings.text: The substantive clause gives the exemption and the proviso qualifies the substantive clause. In effect the proviso says that part of the turnover of the selling dealer covered by the terms of sub-cl. ii will be exempted provided a declaration in the form prescribed is furnished. To put it in other words, a dealer cannot get the exemption unless he furnishes the declaration in the prescribed form.

anchor.surface_text: The substantive clause gives the exemption and the proviso qualifies the substantive clause. In effect the proviso says that part of the turnover of the selling dealer covered by the terms of sub-cl. ii will be exempted provided a declaration in the form prescribed is furnished.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.5(2)(a)(ii) qualifies substantive exemption making furnishing of prescribed declaration mandatory condition precedent; ordinary rules of proviso construction apply.

holdings.text: The expression on demand only fixes the point of time when the declaration forms are to be produced otherwise the rule would be inconsistent with the section.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does r. 27A support the contrary construction. The expression on demand only fixes the point of time when the declaration forms are to be produced otherwise the rule would be inconsistent with the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of s.5(2)(a)(ii) and r.27A: 'on demand' specifies time for furnishing declaration required by section.

holdings.text: Section 21A on which reliance is placed has no bearing on the question to be decided. It only empowers the Commissioner or any person appointed to assist him under sub-s. 1 of s. 3 to take evidence on oath etc. It can be invoked only in a case where the authority concerned is empowered to take evidence in respect of any particular matter but that does not enable him to ignore a statutory condition to claim exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Section 21A on which reliance is placed has no bearing on the question to be decided. It only empowers the Commissioner or any person appointed to assist him under sub-s. 1 of s. 3 to take evidence on oath etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summoning power under s.21A does not override or substitute the mandatory statutory requirement of furnishing declaration forms.

holdings.text: Sub-rules 3 and 4 of r. 27A are not helpful to the appellant. They provide only safeguards against abuse of the declaration forms by the purchasing dealers they do not enable the selling dealer to either directly apply or to compel the purchasing dealers to apply for duplicate forms nor do they enjoin on the appropriate authority to give the selling dealer a duplicate form to replace lost one.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-rules 3 and 4 of r. 27A are not helpful to the appellant. They provide only safeguards against abuse of the declaration forms by the purchasing dealers they do not enable the selling dealer to either directly apply or to compel the purchasing dealers to apply for duplicate forms

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.27A sub-rules prevent misuse of forms but contain no provision for issuance of duplicate declarations.

holdings.text: But it is for the Legislature or for the rule-making authority to intervene to soften the rigour of the provisions and it is not for this Court to do so where the provisions are clear and unambiguous.

anchor.surface_text: We realise that the section and the rules as they stand may conceivably cause unmerited hardship to an honest dealer. He may have lost the declaration forms by a pure accident, such as fire, theft etc., and yet he will be penalised for something for which he is not responsible. But it is for the Legislature or for the rule-making authority to intervene to soften the rigour of the provisions and it is not for this Court to do so where the provisions are clear and unambiguous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear statutory provisions cannot be rewritten by court to avoid hardship; remedy lies with legislature or rule-maker.

holdings.text: There is an understandable reason for the stringency of the provisions. The object of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act and the rules made thereunder is self-evident. While they are obviously intended to give exemption to a dealer in respect of sales to registered dealers of specified classes of goods, it seeks also to prevent fraud and collusion in an attempt to evade tax.

anchor.surface_text: There is an understandable reason for the stringency of the provisions. The object of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act and the rules made thereunder is self-evident. While they are obviously intended to give exemption to a dealer in respect of sales to registered dealers of specified classes of goods, it seeks also to prevent fraud and collusion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stringent requirements justified by policy to prevent fraud, collusion, and administrative inconvenience in verifying resale purpose.

holdings.text: The decision of this Court in The State of Orissa v. M.A. Tulloch and Co. Ltd. does not help the appellant. That decision was concerned with s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947. That section was similar in terms to s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in question, but there was no proviso to that section in the Orissa Act similar to the one found in the present section. That makes all the difference, for it is the proviso that imposes the condition.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in The State of Orissa v. M.A. Tulloch and Co. Ltd. 1  does not help the appellant. That decision was concerned with s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947. That section was similar in terms to s. 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in question, but there was no proviso to that section

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orissa case distinguishable as lacking conditioning proviso; rule held directory there unlike mandatory proviso here.

precedents.cited_proposition: The rule under the Orissa Sales Tax Act requiring production of declaration forms is directory and substantial compliance is sufficient as it is inconsistent with the section which lacks a proviso imposing the condition.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in effect exempts a specified turnover of a dealer from sales tax. The provision prescribing the exemption shall, therefore, be strictly construed. The substantive clause gives the exemption and the proviso qualifies the substantive clause. In effect the proviso says that part of the turnover of the selling dealer covered by the terms of sub-cl. ii will be exempted provided a declaration in the form prescribed is furnished.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in effect exempts a specified turnover of a dealer from sales tax. The provision prescribing the exemption shall, therefore, be strictly construed.

Section 5 2  a  ii  of the Act in effect exempts a specified turnover of a dealer from sales tax. The provision prescribing the exemption shall, therefore, be strictly construed. The substantive clause gives the exemption and the proviso qualifies the substantive clause. In effect the proviso says that part of the turnover of the selling dealer covered by the terms of sub-cl. ii will be exempted provided a declaration in the form prescribed is furnished.
